awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Coordinated Power Management in Colocation Data Centers
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Coordinated Power Management in Colocation Data Centers

This project focuses on optimizing power management in colocation data centers, which provide facility support to multiple tenants that manage their own servers in shared space. As an integral segment of data center industry supporting the exploding information technology demand, multi-tenant colocation data centers have been massively expanding in both number and scale. The significant concerns are both growing operational costs and environmental issues. Nonetheless, the existing energy-efficiency efforts have been dominantly focused on owner-operated data centers, like Google, whose operators have full and coordinated control over both computing resources and facilities, and hence they are not applicable for colocation data centers in which individual tenants manage their own servers and power consumption in a non-coordinated manner. Consequently, colocation data centers are far behind state-of-the-art owner-operated data centers in energy efficiency and sustainability, which, if left unaddressed, is a major hurdle for sustainable growth in digital economy.

To achieve energy sustainability in colocation data centers, this project proposes novel market-based approaches to coordinate individual tenants' power management, in concert with optimizing colocation operator's own server management and non-IT control (e.g., cooling system). This project investigates three complementary research thrusts: (i) Holistically optimizing colocation operator's facility management and economic incentives offered to tenants for energy saving, to limit the usage of carbon-intensive electricity; (ii) Enabling colocation data center demand response to minimize colocation operator's operating cost, increase the adoption of renewable energy, and enhance the power grid reliability; and (iii) Experimentation and validation based on combined software simulation, system prototyping, and real-world implementation.

As part of the collaborative efforts from both industry and academia to enable sustainable computing, this project uniquely extends the exploration of power management from owner-operated data centers to multi-tenant colocation data centers. This project can catalyze a shift in future data center management and transform the way that the digital economy evolves, bearing great economic, environmental and societal impacts. This project also contains a significant educational component and provides broad opportunities to attract a diverse population of students to engage in computer science.

por.por_cntn:
Multi-tenant colocation data centers have been massively expanding in both number and scale. The significant concerns are both growing operational costs and environmental issues. Nonetheless, the existing energy-efficiency efforts have been dominantly focused on owner-operated data centers, like Google, whose operators have full and coordinated control over both computing resources and facilities, and hence they are not directly applicable for multi-tenant colocation data centers in which individual tenants typically manage their own servers and power consumption in a non-coordinated manner. Consequently, multi-tenant data centers are often behind state-of-the-art owner-operated data centers in energy efficiency, resilience and sustainability, which, if left unaddressed, can be a major hurdle for sustainable growth in digital economy. This CAREER grant supported our research to develop novel algorithms to enable advances in energy efficiency, resilience, sustainability, and demand response of multi-tenant data centers.

Focusing on multi-tenant colocation data centers, this project developed novel algorithms using a variety of interdisciplinary tools, such as online learning, optimization and game theory, to exploit the potential of enabling coordinated power management, both among different tenants and between IT and non-IT components. The algorithms can effectively lower the data center-level peak demand and reduce energy footprint for all participating tenants, while satisfying various requirements on data center operation and enhancing the resilience of shared data center capacities. The algorithms can also be integrated with state-of-the-art power management techniques to optimize individual tenants' power-cost-resilience tradeoff at runtime. Importantly, the algorithms developed in this project represent some of the earliest solutions that leverage interdisciplinary tools to achieve efficient and coordinated power management in multi-tenant data centers. In addition, the algorithms and methodologies from this project can potentially apply to other systems beyond data centers, benefiting the design and innovation in other domains. For example, the market-based approaches to enabling coordinated power management in multi-tenant data centers may apply broadly to resource management and optimization problems with self-interested agents.

Going beyond data center sustainability, demand response has been a proven and effective tool for achieving grid-level resilience and sustainability. While warehouse-scale data centers are traditionally viewed as energy hogs, this negative view has been quickly changing in recent years. Specifically, unlike traditional loads, data centers have great flexibility for demand response by adjusting their energy demands using a wide range of control knobs, such as turning off unused servers, spatially shifting workloads to elsewhere, and deferring non-urgent workloads. Thus, an important focus of this project was to enable efficient demand response of data centers, especially multi-tenant data centers, by designing new optimization algorithms and market approaches that can help reshape the data center-level energy demands in reaction to demand response signals to enhance the resilience and sustainability of power grids. Nonetheless, there are several technical challenges. For example, for demand responses at runtime, grid operators often face an uncertain environment resulting from several factors such as intermittent renewables and dynamic energy demands of users. Such uncertainties also create significant challenges for data centers as switching on/off servers in quick response to demand response signals can be costly. To address these challenges, this project tapped into tools such as online optimization, mechanism design and learning, and developed various novel algorithms to regulate data center energy demand by holistically optimizing power management in response to time-varying demand response signals. The algorithms developed in this project have theoretical bounds that provide a rigorous performance characterization under various settings.

While the research results from this grant are rooted in data centers, they have the potential for broader impact in other areas through the development of advanced optimization, control, and learning tools for optimally managing complex networked multi-agent systems.  For example, individual workloads in multi-tenant data centers are important contextual information for system-level coordination, but they can only be predicted in practice subject to possibly very large prediction errors. Thus, the algorithms in this project can provide new perspectives and potentially apply for optimizing real-world systems where the input information is inaccurate. Finally, as part of the grant, the PI has supported in part multiple PhD students, integrated the research into the existing curriculum at UCR, and attracted students from under-represented groups to engage in STEM careers.
